text: Now before we go further I want to talk about our player controller because we're going to actually be creating a brand new player controller for this interaction logic to go into and the reason for this is because we want the player no matter if it's a player or a car or a spaceship or a ball to be able to press the E key on their keyboard and be able to interact with this light switch and this is a really key. Importance of building things inside of one real we always want to make sure that we build stuff in the correct location now we could build all of this functionality that we're building in each one of these classes we could build it inside of our player inside of our car inside of our spaceship or inside of our ball but that means that there are now four locations where we need to maintain our code since the player controller acts as a way to take different ponds over while we're building. While still giving the user the same type of input based off the device they're using we can input code or implement code inside of our player controller and have that accessible to the user no matter the type of pond that they are so let's go ahead and pop over here to the editor really quick and I'm hit control space and we're going to right click inside of here we're going to go to our blueprint class and then from our pick parent class we're going to look for our player controller. I'm going to call this BP underscore interaction interaction controller let's go ahead and double click on it to open it up now to understand what we're going to do next let's take a look at the following image so what we're going to be doing is we are going to be creating a line in space and that line is going to start in the center of our character and it's going to go out at X distance that we define and it's going to be anything that is inside of that line. We can determine different properties about it and for us what we're going to be doing is we're going to be casting this line X unit out into space and we're going to see if that line comes in contact with an object that contains our interface and if it does then we'll be able to do something with it so again this is an example here a visual example of what we're going to be creating we're going to be creating a line that goes out into 3D space that starts at our players center and has an endpoint and we're going to use this to determine if we are looking at a light switch or not so here's a breakdown of the nodes that we're going to be using so we're going to use our input action interact is our trigger. Then what we're going to do is we're going to use a combination of our get actor location are get controlled pawn and our get actor forward vector to determine the location and the rotation that the player is currently facing in the world and we're going to use that. Inside of our line trace by channel node we're going to use this to give us a start and an ending value and once we've done that we can do it then do things off of our out hit which will describe here in just a little bit so let's go ahead and come over to the editor now and we're to come over to our event graph and let's go ahead and start adding stuff so for things first we're going to look for our IA underscore and look at that we have our IA interact. So at the beginning of our line trace and then what we're going to do is we're going to take the forward vector we're going to multiply that by a float value say 2000 and then we're going to multiply that by the actor location and this is going to act as the end of our line trace.
